Name: On the Sizes and Distances of the Sun and Moon
Metaphysical Tags: Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Cosmological Rationalism), Genesis (Process Realism)
Short Description: Astronomical Treatise in Ancient Greek that applies geometry and observation to calculate the relative magnitudes and distances of the Sun, Moon, and Earth. Aristarchus demonstrates that the Sun is vastly larger than the Earth, and the Earth larger than the Moon — a radical challenge to the scientific status quo, which had long assumed Earth’s primacy in size and cosmic centrality. By grounding his claims in mathematical reasoning, Aristarchus inaugurated a decisive shift toward empirical and quantitative cosmology.
Neumann Stages Tags: Separation from World Parents, Mythic Ordering of Reality
Name.1: On the Sizes and Distances of the Sun and Moon
Author: Aristarchus of Samos
Literary Forms Tags: Doctrine / Treatise, Essay / Inquiry, Manual / Instruction, Analysis
Literary Content Tags: Empirical, Didactic, Epistemological / Hermeneutics, Cosmological, Metaphysical

Name: Decree of Bargylia Honoring Attalus I
Arts and Sciences Tags: Human Sciences: Political Science/Law, Human Sciences: Public Relations, Liberal Arts: History
Short Description: A public decree issued by a Greek city-state to commemorate and legitimize the benefactions of King Attalus I of Pergamon. Formally inscribed for public display, the text praises Attalus for his military protection, civic generosity, religious piety, and support of Hellenic freedom. The decree resolves to honor the king with a golden crown, public statue, and permanent inscription, reinforcing diplomatic bonds between the city and the Attalid kingdom.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Persona, Hero, Father Archetype, Wise Old Man

Name: Teos Decree for the Dionysiac Artists
Short Description: The text granted inviolability, tax exemptions, and travel rights to the guild of actors and performers in honor of Dionysus. It meant to attract and protect artists who ensured the city’s prestige by enriching its festivals and linking it to a wider cultural network. Dionysus’ cult was vital because he embodied theater, performance, and communal ecstasy, making him the divine guarantor of civic spectacle. By tying legal privileges to Dionysus, Teos turned religious devotion into political capital, projecting itself as a hub of Dionysiac culture.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Anima, Initiator, Self, Father Archetype, Hero
Neumann Stages Tags: Divine Intervention, Initiation, Return to the Community, Mythic Ordering of Reality

Name: Antiochus III Letter to Sardis
Arts and Sciences Tags: Human Sciences: Political Science/Law, Human Sciences: Public Relations, Liberal Arts: History
Short Description: A royal decree granting Sardis tax relief and civic privileges. Antiochus sought to secure loyalty from a strategically important Anatolian city by alleviating economic burdens and presenting himself as a beneficent ruler. The Seleucid king’s intent was to stabilize imperial control, reinforce dynastic legitimacy, and keep Sardis firmly integrated within the Hellenistic imperial network.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Father Archetype, Wise Old Man, Persona, Initiator

Name: Parian Decree for the Games of Artemis
Short Description: Civic decree recording Paros’ acceptance of Magnesia’s invitation to join the newly established Leukophryena Games in honor of Artemis Leukophryene. These games were modeled after the great Panhellenic festivals, combining religious worship, athletic contests, and cultural display to elevate Magnesia’s prestige and bind other poleis into a network of shared ritual life. By inscribing its acceptance, Paros affirmed its piety toward Artemis and at the same time engaged in a form of diplomatic communication: participation meant recognition of Magnesia’s festival as worthy of pan-Hellenic status. This was not just religious but political — games were tools of soft power, forging inter-polis alliances, normalizing cooperation, and creating a common cultural language of Greek identity.
Neumann Stages Tags: Divine Intervention, Initiation, Return to the Community, Mythic Ordering of Reality

Name: Sacred Space Regulation Edict (Pergamon)
Metaphysical Tags: Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Monism, Inversion (Subversive Ontology), Clockwork (Cosmological Rationalism)
Short Description: Outlines rules governing ritual purity, access, and conduct within a temple sanctuary. Issued by civic and/or priestly authorities, the text defines sacred boundaries, prescribes purification requirements, and imposes fines for transgressions. It reflects the fusion of civic law and religious order typical of the Hellenistic polis, where divine harmony and social discipline are maintained through legal and ritual precision. The text was issued in Hellenistic Anatolia but survives through a later Roman Imperial Copy.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Persona, Self, Initiator, Father Archetype, Terrible Father

Name: Conics
Arts and Sciences Tags: Foundational Abstract Sciences: Mathematics, Foundational Abstract Sciences: Geometry, Foundational Abstract Sciences: Logic/Formal Reasoning, Liberal Arts: Philosophy, Liberal Arts: Art/Aesthetics
Short Description: A monumental mathematical treatise that systematically defines and analyzes the three fundamental curves—ellipse, parabola, and hyperbola—as sections of a cone sliced by a plane. The work spans eight books (with the first four surviving in Greek and the rest in Arabic translation) and lays the foundation for much of analytic geometry, astronomy, and physics. Apollonius introduces new terminology, offers rigorous geometric proofs, and classifies the properties of conic sections with unprecedented precision. The text carries deep philosophical implications, portraying the cosmos as a space of elegant, intelligible form.
Author: Apollonius of Perga
Literary Forms Tags: Doctrine / Treatise, Manual / Instruction, Glossary / Taxonomy, Analysis

Name: Festival Regulations for Zeus Sosipolis
Arts and Sciences Tags: Human Sciences: Political Science/Law, Human Sciences: Education
Short Description: Ritual and civic rules for the cult of Zeus as “Savior of the City.” Structured like a sacred law, it prescribes sacrifices, priestly purity, initiation requirements, and civic oversight by magistrates. The text served as both a ritual manual and a political-theological decree, reinforcing the unity of polis, law, and divine protection.

Name: Honorific Decrees for Moschion, Krates, Zosimos
Metaphysical Tags: Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Genesis (Process Realism), Multiplicities (Plural Ontologies), War (Dialectical Materialism)
Arts and Sciences Tags: Human Sciences: Political Science/Law, Human Sciences: Public Relations, Liberal Arts: History
Short Description: Civic inscriptions issued by the council and people of a polis to publicly recognize the benefactions of three elite citizens. Moschion was praised for his zeal and loyalty to the community, embodying the role of the civic hero. Krates, a wealthy benefactor, financed festivals, public works, and city defenses, ensuring the prosperity and cultural life of the polis. Zosimos distinguished himself through embassies and military service, safeguarding the city’s security and reputation abroad. These decrees follow the standard civic formula — justification of service, resolution to honor, and public inscription — and served to legitimize civic authority, normalize elite generosity (euergetism), and project civic values to both citizens and foreigners.
Neumann Stages Tags: Initiation, Return to the Community, Mythic Ordering of Reality, Coronation of the King

Name: Nemrut Dağ Inscriptions of Antiochus I
Metaphysical Tags: Genesis (Process Realism), Multiplicities (Plural Ontologies), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Cosmological Rationalism)
Arts and Sciences Tags: Human Sciences: Political Science/Law, Human Sciences: Public Relations, Liberal Arts: History
Short Description: Monumental decrees carved in Greek that set out ritual regulations and proclaim the king’s divine status. Antiochus declares himself the founder of a new cult uniting Zoroastrian deities (Oromasdes, Mithras, Artagnes) with Hellenic gods (Zeus, Apollo, Herakles), creating a deliberate synthesis of East and West. The text establishes calendar-linked ceremonies, priestly obligations, and hereditary duties, embedding Antiochus within a cosmic and dynastic order. Politically, it legitimized his fragile kingdom by rooting it in both Persian and Hellenic traditions, marking the Hellenistic age of syncretism.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Self, Hero, Wise Old Man, Father Archetype, Persona
Neumann Stages Tags: Divine Intervention, Initiation, Death, Rebirth, Mythic Ordering of Reality, Coronation of the King
